sentences.original: kîtahtawê ayîsiyiniwak êh-wîkicik, kîtahtawê ômis îtwêw pêyak nâpêw;
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ayîsiyiniwak ê-wîkicik kîtahtawê ômisi itwêw pêyak nâpêw
sentences.english: Once upon a time, as some people dwelt somewhere, a certain man spoke as follows;

sentences.original: ôhih owîcêwâkanah, ây, itêw, nawac sipwêhtêtân, itêw,
sentences.english: to his comrade he said, “Now then, let us set out;
you may tell a few people;
seven of us shall go,” he told him.
“Very well.”
“Two nights from now we shall set out.
We shall look for Blackfoot, to steal their horses when we find them.

sentences.original: mâka wâpamikoyahkwâwi, wîh-kakwê-nipahikoyahkwâwi, kiyâna mîna ka-kakwê-nipahânawak, itêw.
sentences.english: And if they catch sight of us and try to kill us, we shall try to kill them,” he told him.
“Very well.”
Accordingly, after two nights they set out.

sentences.original: awa pêyak nâpêsis ôhtâwiya êh-okimâwiyit, misatimwah itêh êy-ayâyit, êkotêh ayâw, kâ-wâpamât êh-pimohtêyit ôhi kâ-sipwêhtêyit.
sentences.text: awa pêyak nâpêsis ôhtâwiya ê-okimâwiyit misatimwa itê ê-ayâyit êkotê ayâw kâ-wâpamât ê-pimohtêyit ôhi kâ-sipwêhtêyit
sentences.english: A certain young boy, whose father was chief, was where the horses were, and saw them go off who were setting out.
When he looked at them, “Surely they are going off!” he thought;

sentences.original: acosisah êh-ayât awa nâpêsis, kêkâc âta wiya êh-oskinîkit awa nâpêsis;
sentences.text: acosisa ê-ayât awa nâpêsis kêkâc âta wiya ê-oskinîkit awa nâpêsis
sentences.english: at the age of having arrows was the boy, though, indeed, he was close to adolescence;
“Oh, do let me go with them!”
That was his thought.
Accordingly he followed them.

sentences.original: itêh êh-otâkosiniyik, ê-wîh-minahoyit, wistah êkotê takohtêw.
sentences.text: itê ê-otâkosiniyik ê-wî-minahoyit wîsta êkotê takohtêw
sentences.english: At the place they reached toward evening, as they were about to kill game,  he too arrived.
His father did not know that he had gone off.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki nâpêwak kâh-minahocik, kâ-takohtêyit ôhi nâpêsisah, nisitawêyimêwak ôhtâwiyiwa êh-okimâwiyit.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki nâpêwak kâ-minahocik kâ-takohtêyit ôhi nâpêsisa nisitawêyimêwak ôhtâwîyiwa ê-okimâwiyit
sentences.english: And those men, when they had killed game and the boy arrived, recognized  him as the chief's son.
They did not care to say anything to him.

sentences.original: êkos êh-kîsitêpocik, ê-wîh-mîcisocik, miyw-asamêwak ôhi nâpêsisah.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-kîsitêpocik ê-wî-mîcisocik miyo-asamêwak ôhi nâpêsisa
sentences.english: So, when they cooked their meal and were about to eat, they gave the boy plenty of food.
“Well, let us treat him kindly.
He is our chief's son,” they said.
Then they slept there.
The next morning they went on.
Where they were by dark, they camped for the night.

sentences.original: mwêhci nikotwâsikwâw êh-kîh-nipâcik, môhkiciwanipêk itah êh-ayâyik, cîk êkotah mostoswah ayâyiwa.
sentences.text: mwêhci nikotwâsikwâw ê-kî-nipâcik môhkiciwanipêk ita ê-ayâyik cîki êkota mostoswa ayâyiwa
sentences.english: When they had slept six nights on the way, near a spring of water were some buffalos.
“Now then, let one man go shoot them.

sentences.original: nipahâcih, êkotah ka-kapêsinânaw, kik-ôsîhtâyahk ta-nîmâyahk, itêw.
sentences.english: If he kills any, we shall camp there and prepare provisions for the march,” the leader told them.
Accordingly one set out to kill buffalos.
He killed one.

sentences.original: cîkih êh-sakâyik êkwah itohtêwak ôki kotakak.
sentences.text: cîki ê-sakâyik êkwa itohtêwak ôki kotakak
sentences.english: The others went to a near-by grove.

sentences.original: êh-takohtêcik êkotah, âsay ôma kâ-pâskiswât mostoswah.
sentences.text: ê-takohtêcik êkota âsay ôma kâ-pâskiswât mostoswa
sentences.english: When they got to it, he had already shot the buffalo.

sentences.original: pêhtamiyiwa ayahciyiniwah namoya wâhyaw êh-ayâyit, mitâtaht êy-ihtasiyit, mîn êyakonik nêhiyawah êh-ntonawâcik.
sentences.text: pêhtamiyiwa ayahciyiniwa namôya wâhyaw ê-ayâyit mitâtaht ê-ihtasiyit mîna êyakonik nêhiyawa ê-nitonawâcik
sentences.english: The sound was heard by some Blackfoot who were not far from there, ten in number, themselves looking for Cree.
They decided  to take a look at the Cree.

sentences.original: pôtih wâpamikok nêhiyawak ôki kâ-wiyinihtâkêcik têpakohp kêy-ihtasicik êkwah awa pêyak nâpêsis, êkosi ayênânîw.
sentences.text: pôti wâpamikwak nêhiyawak ôki kâ-wiyanihtâkêcik têpakohp kê-ihtasicik êkwa awa pêyak nâpêsis êkosi ayinânêw
sentences.english: And there they saw those Cree preparing their carcass, seven of them, with the boy, a total of eight.
Accordingly the Blackfoot crept up on the Cree.
The latter did not know of their presence.

sentences.original: mêkwâc êh-wiyinihtâkêcik, nam êskw êh-nawacîcik, âsay pâskisokwak ôki nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: mêkwâc ê-wiyanihtâkêcik nama isko ê-nawacîcik âsay pâskisokwak ôki nêhiyawak
sentences.english: While they were cutting up the game, before they had begun the roasting, the Blackfoot fired at the Cree.

sentences.original: oma kâ-sakâyik êkotah êh-itâmocik, pêyak pahkisin nêhiyaw, oskâtihk êh-tawahoht, êh-nâtwâpayiyik oskât.
sentences.text: ôma kâ-sakâyik êkota ê-itâmocik pêyak pahkisin nêhiyaw oskâtihk ê-tawahoht ê-nâtwâpayiyik oskât
sentences.english: As they fled toward the wooded place, one of the Cree fell, his leg pierced by a bullet and broken.
The grown men fled.

sentences.original: awa nâpêsis nakîw, ê-kisâtât ôhi kâ-kaskâtahomiht, êh-têpwêt, ahâ, nitôtêmitik, wîhtamawâhkêk nôhtâwiy : namoya niwîh-nakatâw awa.
sentences.text: awa nâpêsis nakîw ê-kisâtât ôhi kâ-kaskatahomiht ê-têpwêt
sentences.english: The boy stopped and stayed by the wounded man, crying, “Hey, friends, tell my father when you see him: I shall not leave this man.
I don't care if I too am killed,” he told them, calling to them.

sentences.original: âsay wâhyaw êh-atimipahtâyit owîcêwâkaniwâwa, êkwah âhci pikoh êh-pâskisokocik ayahciyiniwah, âskaw môskîstawêw, âta wyah êh-pimwât.
sentences.text: âsay wâhyaw ê-atimipahtâyit owîcêwâkaniwâwa êkwa âhci piko ê-pâskisokocik ayahciyiniwa âskaw môskîstawêw âta wiya ê-pimwât
sentences.english: When their comrades had run far away, and the Blackfoot were still shooting at them, he took the offensive against them from time to time, firing at them.

sentences.original: êkwah awa kâ-kaskatahoht êwako simatapiw, wîstah êh-pâskiswât, wîstah êh-nôtinikêt;
sentences.text: êkwa awa kâ-kaskatahoht êwako simatapiw wîsta ê-pâskiswât wîsta ê-nôtinikêt
sentences.english: And the man whose bone had been broken sat up, and he too fired at them, joining in the fight;

sentences.original: mâka nama kêkway kîh-nipahêwak, êh-mitâtasiyit, êkwah wiyawâw êh-nîsicik awa nâpêsis.
sentences.text: mâka nama kêkway kî-nipahêwak ê-mitâtasiyit êkwa wiyawâw ê-nîsicik awa nâpêsis
sentences.english: but they did not succeed in killing any of them, for the others were ten, and they only two, one of them a boy.
For their comrades had left them behind.

sentences.original: piyisk pôyoyiwa ôh iyahciyiniwah, êh-kostikocik, ê-sipwêhtêyit.
sentences.text: piyisk pôyoyiwa ôhi ayahciyiniwa ê-kostikocik ê-sipwêhtêyit
sentences.english: At last the Blackfoot, fearing them, gave up and went away.

sentences.original: êkwah awa nâpêsis iyikohk êh-wâpamât wâhyaw êh-atimohtêyit, êkwah itohtêw mohkiciwanipêkohk, itah êh-tipinawâyik êkotah êh-miskahk.
sentences.text: êkwa awa nâpêsis iyikohk ê-wâpamât wâhyaw ê-atimohtêyit êkwa itohtêw môhkiciwanipêkohk ita ê-tipinawâyik êkota ê-miskahk
sentences.english: Then the boy, as soon as he saw that they had gone far away, went to the spring and found a sheltered place.
Then he went to the wounded man.
“Come, I have found a place where we can stay,” he told him.
“Oh, no, my boy! Do go home!
Your father is chief; he will grieve.
You will only suffer here.
My leg will not get well so very soon.
Go home!” he told the boy.

sentences.original: â, namoya! iyikohk miyw-ayâyani, kîwêyini, êkoyikohk nika-kîwân.
sentences.english: “Oh, no! When you are well and go home, then I shall go home.
Whenever my father tells stories, I always hear him say,  'One is counted a brave man, if one stays with those who have been  left behind.'
That is why I mean to stay with you,” he told him.

sentences.original: êkosi itohtêw awa nâpêsis ôhi wiyâsah;
sentences.text: êkosi itohtêw awa nâpêsis ôhi wiyâsa
sentences.english: Thereupon the boy went to where the meat was;

sentences.original: askêkin otinam, êkotah êh-otapêt ôh ôskinîkiwa, sakâhk êh-itohtahât.
sentences.text: askêkin otinam êkota ê-otâpêt ôhi oskinîkiwa sakâhk ê-itohtahât
sentences.english: he took the hide, and on it dragged the young man to the grove of trees.

sentences.original: om îtah kâ-tipinawâyik ê-kîh-pêsiwât, êkwah wiyâsah awatâw.
sentences.text: ôma ita kâ-tipinawâyik ê-kî-pêsiwât êkwa wiyâsa awatâw
sentences.english: When he had brought him to the sheltered place, he fetched the meats.
He took all the meat.

sentences.original: êkwah kotawêw, êkwah êh-kîsitêpot ta-mîcisocik, êkwah mînah nipiy êh-otinahk wînâstakayêpicikanihk, ta-minihkwêyit ôhi nâpêwa.
sentences.text: êkwa kotawêw êkwa ê-kîsitêpot ta-mîcisocik êkwa mîna nipiy ê-otinahk wînâstakayêpicikanihk ta-minihkwêyit ôhi nâpêwa
sentences.english: Then he built a fire and cooked, that they might eat, and drew water in the paunch, that the man might drink.
So the latter drank and ate.

sentences.original: êh-kîsi-mîcisot, êkwah miscikosah kâh-kîskataham êh-apisâsiniyikih, ôma kâ-pîkopayiyik oskât, êkotah êh-tahkopitamwât ôm ôskâtiyiw.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-mîcisot êkwa miscikosa kâ-kîskataham ê-apisâsiniyiki ôma kâ-pîkopayiyik oskât êkota ê-tahkopitamwât ôma oskâtiyiw
sentences.english: When he had eaten, he hewed some small sticks to shape, putting a splint on his leg where it was broken.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-kîsi-tahkopitahk, êkwah osîhtâw wîkiwâw nîpiyah ohci, êkotah êh-ayât, êkwah êw-osîhtât kâhkêwakwah ana nâpêw, êkwah awah nâpêsis tahkih êh-asawâpit.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-kîsi-tahkopitahk êkwa osîhtâw wîkiwâw nîpiya ohci êkota ê-ayât êkwa ê-osîhtât kâhkêwakwa ana nâpêw êkwa awa nâpêsis tahki ê-asawâpit
sentences.english: When he had tied it up, he built a hut for them of leaves, where the man stayed, preparing dried meat, while the boy always kept a lookout.
At last it grew dark.
They stayed there.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê, ayênâniw êy-ihtahto-tipiskâyik êkotah êh-ayâcik, kâ-wâpamât êh-niyânaniyit ayîsiyiniwah êh-pêc-âstamohtêyit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ayinânêw ê-ihtahto-tipiskâyik êkota ê-ayâcik kâ-wâpamât ê-niyânaniyit ayîsiyiniwa ê-pêci-âstamohtêyit
sentences.english: Presently, when they had been there eight nights, he saw five men coming toward them.

sentences.original: êh-ka-kitâpamât, âsay mâka êh-otâkosiniyik, pôtih itah k-âyâcik cîk êkotah kapêsiyiwa, êy-osîhtâyit wîkiyiw, tâpiskôc wâskahikan êh-itahâyit mistikwah.
sentences.text: ê-ka-kitâpamât âsay mâka ê-otâkosiniyik pôti ita kâ-ayâcik cîki êkota kapêsiyiwa ê-osîhtâyit wîkiyiw tâpiskôc wâskahikan ê-itahâyit mistikwa
sentences.english: As he watched them, as it was evening, he saw them make a camp for the night near to where they were, building a shelter, placing trees in the shape of a wooden house.

sentences.original: êkwah kisiwâk ê-wîh-kakwê-osâpamât, ê-wîh-kakwê-nisitawêyimât kêkw ayisiyiniwah, pôtih iyahciyiniwah.
sentences.text: êkwa kisiwâk ê-wî-kakwê-osâpamât ê-wî-kakwê-nisitawêyimât kêko ayisiyiniwa pôti ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: And when he made an effort to see them at close range, to see what kind of people they were, he saw that they were Blackfoot.

sentences.original: êkosi itohtêw; êkwah ôh ôwîcêwâkanah ômis îtêw : mahtih kipâskisikan pêtâ.
sentences.text: êkosi itohtêw êkwa ôhi owîcêwâkana ômisi itêw
sentences.english: So he went there and said to his companion, “Please give me your gun.

sentences.original: ôtah kisiwâk mahîhkan êh-ayât, nika-pâskiswâw, itêw.
sentences.english: I want to shoot a wolf that is close by here.”
When the other gave it him, he went there.
It was dark by this time.
The others had made a fire and were sitting indoors; he crept up to them.
When he got near them, they were five, a-roasting  of meat.

sentences.original: nawasawâpamôw; tânihi êh-miyohoyit, êwakoni pâskiswêw, ê-sâkowêt.
sentences.text: nawasawâpamôw tânihi ê-miyohoyit êwakoni pâskiswêw ê-sâkowêt
sentences.english: He took careful aim; he shot at those who wore the best clothes, and gave a whoop.
He hit two of them.

sentences.original: êh-tapasiyit nîso, êh-tâh-tawikisiniyit mistikohk, osâm ê-sêkihât, êyakonih mîna pimwêw;
sentences.text: ê-tapasîyit nîso ê-tâh-tâwikisiniyit mistikohk osâm ê-sêkihât êwakoni mîna pimwêw
sentences.english: While two fled, one kept bumping into things, so much had he frightened him; this one too he shot;
sentences.footnote: LB on {nîso}:  Evidently I here missed the word {pêyak}: “one (of them)”.

sentences.english: he killed him too.
So he had killed three.
The other two fled.

sentences.original: êh-kiskêyihtahk êh-tapasiyit; pîhtokêw, otayôwinisiyiwa êh-otinahk, mîna pâskisikan pêyak, pêyak acosisah, pêyak cîkahikani-pakamâkan, êkwah pêyak câpîhcicikanis, môhkomânah nêwo, mîna ostikwâniyihk ôtah ôma êh-manisamwât.
sentences.text: ê-kiskêyihtahk ê-tapasîyit pîhtokêw otayiwinisiyiwa ê-otinahk mîna pâskisikan pêyak pêyak acosisa pêyak cîkahikani-pakamâkan êkwa pêyak câpihcicikanis môhkomâna nêwo mîna ostikwâniyihk ôta ôma ê-manisamwât
sentences.english: When he saw that they had fled, he went inside and took their garments, and a gun, a set of arrows, a tomahawk, and a lance, and four knives, and he cut off this, on their heads here.

sentences.original: kahkiyaw omaskisiniyiwa otinam, êkwah êh-kîwêhtatât, ôhih kâ-kaskatahomiht wîcêwâkanah, êh-pîhtokatât, êh-miyât.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw omaskisiniyiwa otinam êkwa ê-kîwêhtatât ôhi kâ-kaskatahomiht wîcêwâkana ê-pîhtokatât ê-miyât
sentences.english: He took all their moccasins, and took it all back with him and gave it, when he brought it into their hut, to his wounded companion.
He was much surprised, and asked him, “Where did you get it all?”

sentences.original: êh-niyânanicik otah ê-kapêsicik ayahciyiniwak, nisto ninipahâwak, êkotah ôhi êy-ohtinamân, itêw;
sentences.english: “Five Blackfoot camped here for the night; I killed three of them and took these,” he told him;
“I suppose you heard gunshot.”
“Yes.”
That was when I shot two of them.

sentences.original: êkwah pêyak osâm êtokê ê-sêkisit, êh-tâh-tawikisihk, min êwako nipimwâw; ninipahâw.
sentences.english: And one, I suppose because he was frightened, bumped into things, and I shot him too; I killed him.
That makes three.”
“Really, young man, you do not seem to be afraid of them!” the other said to him.
The man was glad.
Then they stayed there.
Now, it seems that those others had their camp not far from there.
Those Blackfoot  who had fled arrived at their camp;
they told how their comrades  had been slain, and that only they were alive.
After four nights, there, the boy saw the Blackfoot coming, moving up their camp.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah ohci ka-kitâpamêw, kisiwâk êkotah kâ-pê-kapêsiyit, êh-mihcêtiyit.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota ohci ka-kitâpamêw kisiwâk êkota kâ-pê-kapêsiyit ê-mihcêtiyit
sentences.english: From where he was, he watched them, as they came to pitch camp close by, a great number of them.
And those whom he had killed were fetched and taken back.
He continued to watch them.
At last darkness came on.
When it was quite dark, he went to where his companion was.
“You had better not light any fire.

sentences.original: kêkway niwâpahtên; mâka namoya nikiskêyihtên kêkway.
sentences.english: I see something; but I do not know what it is.
I think I shall go try to hear what it is,” he told him.
With that he went off again, and went to the camp.
They had not tied up their horses;
he took ten horses, stealing them from the Blackfoot.
He came back to his companion.
“Now then, comrade, what shall we do?
It seems that Blackfoot are camping close by;

sentences.original: mâka âsay mitâtaht otêmiwâwa ôtah nipêsîmâwa!
sentences.english: in fact I am bringing ten of their horses now!”

sentences.original: hay hay itwêyiwa; tâpwê kitatamihin, niwîcêwâkan!
sentences.english: “Splendid!” said he; “Truly, you delight me, comrade!”
“We shall go home, making our escape,” he said to him;
“They will not be able to pursue us;
the horses are not many,” he told him.

sentences.original: tâpwê pêyak pê-takohtahêw wîkiwâhk, êkwah êh-wayawîtâcimoyit owîcêwâkanah, êh-oyahpitât otakohpisiwâwa ohci, êh-têhtahât owîcêwâkanah.
sentences.text: tâpwê pêyak pê-takohtahêw wîkiwâhk êkwa ê-wayawîtâcimoyit owîcêwâkana ê-oyahpitât otakohpisiwâwa ohci ê-têhtahât owîcêwâkana
sentences.english: Accordingly he brought one of the horses to their hut, dragged out his companion, tied him up with their blanket-robes, and set him on the horse.

sentences.original: hâ, niwîcêwâkan, kiya kinakacihtân nîkân ohci.
sentences.english: “Now, comrade, you know how to lead.
I shall drive on the horses.

sentences.original: mîna ka-kiskêyihtên tân-êyikohk ka-pimipayiyin, kiskât ôma ka-manâcihtâyin, itêw.
sentences.english: Besides, you will know how far to ride without injuring your leg,” he told him.

sentences.original: mistahi miywêyihtam aw ôskinîkiw, êkwah ê-sipwê-têhtapit, ê-pê-sîhkitisahwâyit ôhi nâpêsisah misatimwah.
sentences.text: mistahi miywêyihtam awa oskinîkiw êkwa ê-sipwê-têhtapit ê-pê-sîhkitisahwâyit ôhi nâpêsisa misatimwa
sentences.english: The young man was very glad, and rode away, while the boy drove on the horses.
They rode all night.

sentences.original: êh-kîsikâyik, êh-wâpamât ôw ôskinîkiw misatimwah, tâpwêh miyosiwak! itêyihtam.
sentences.text: ê-kîsikâyik ê-wâpamât awa oskinîkiw misatimwa itêyihtam
sentences.english: When day came and the young man saw the horses, “Really, they are fine ones!” he thought.
They fled all day, and again all night.
For two nights they did not sleep.

sentences.original: êkoyikohk êh-wâpamâcik mostoswah, nawaswêw awa nâpêsis.
sentences.text: êkoyikohk ê-wâpamâcik mostoswa nawaswêw awa nâpêsis
sentences.english: Then, as they saw some buffalos, the boy gave chase.
He killed one.

sentences.original: miywêyihtam aw ôskinîkiw, êkotah ê-nîhtakosît, ê-wîh-wiyanihtâkêcik, ê-wîh-mîcisocik.
sentences.text: miywêyihtam awa oskinîkiw êkota ê-nîhtakosît ê-wî-wiyanihtâkêcik ê-wî-mîcisocik
sentences.english: The young man was glad; he dismounted, and they skinned it and cut it up and made ready to eat.

sentences.original: âsay ôtêh wîkiwâhk awa nâpêsis êkwah aw ôskinîkiw mawîhkâtâwak, nipahâwak, êh-itihcik, ôhih ka-kîh-nakatisimikocik êh-itâcimowit.
sentences.text: âsay ôtê wîkiwâhk awa nâpêsis êkwa awa oskinîkiw mawîhkâtâwak ê-itihcik ôhi ka-kî-nakatisimikocik ê-itâcimoyit
sentences.english: Meanwhile, back in their home, this boy and this young man were being mourned; “They were killed,” was said of them, in accordance with the story of those who had abandoned them.

sentences.original: tahkih mâtôyiwa ôhtâwiya awa nâpêsis k-ôkimâwiyit ohtâwiya.
sentences.text: tahki mâtoyiwa ôhtâwiya awa nâpêsis kâ-okimâwi-yit ôhtâwiya
sentences.english: The boy's father, the chief, wept incessantly.

sentences.original: êkwah wiyawâw ê-kisi-wiyanihtâkêcik, êkwah êh-kîsitêpocik, êh-paminawasocik, êyikohk êh-kîsi-mîcisocik, mîna sipwêhtêwak.
sentences.text: êkwa wiyawâw ê-kîsi-wiyanihtâkêcik êkwa ê-kîsitêpocik ê-paminawasocik iyikohk ê-kîsi-mîcisocik mîna sipwêhtêwak
sentences.english: But, as for them, when they had cleaned their game, and cooked their meal, and eaten, they went on.
After two nights on the way, presently they came in sight of their camp.
The one who had been wounded was glad.

sentences.original: ispîh êh-wâpamihcik, êh-pê-sipwêpayit pêyak oskinîkiw, awînik ôk êyakonik, nipahâwak, kâ-kîh-itwêt.
sentences.text: ispî ê-wâpamihcik ê-pê-sipwêpayit pêyak oskinîkiw awîniki ôki êyakonik kâ-kî-itwêt
sentences.english: When they were seen, a young man came to them from the camp; whom did he see, but those of whom it had been said that they were killed!
sentences.footnote: LB on {kâ-kîh-itwêt}:  Probably read as {kâ-kîh-itwêhk}: “it was so reported”, as in translation.

sentences.original: êkotah ohci kîwêpayiw awa, êh-ntawi-wîhtamawât ôh ôkimâwa êh-takosiniyit okosisiyiwa mîn ôhi kâ-kîh-kaskatahomiht,
sentences.text: êkota ohci kîwêpayiw awa ê-nitawi-wîhtamawât ôhi okimâwa ê-takosiniyit okosisiyiwa mîna ôhi kâ-kî-kaskatahomiht
sentences.english: Then this man rode back to tell the chief that his son had come home, as well as the man who had been wounded;
and when they heard this, they went to meet them.

sentences.original: êh-pêtastimwêyit aw ôkosisah, okimâwa, awa nâpêsis ôhih kâ-kaskatahomiht niyânan miyêw misatimwah;
sentences.text: ê-pêtastimwêyit awa okosisa okimâwa awa nâpêsis ôhi kâ-kaskatahomiht niyânan miyêw misatimwa
sentences.english: That boy, the chief's  son, who brought the horses, gave five of them to the man who had been wounded;
five horses he kept.
The chief was very glad.
Then everyone was glad;

sentences.original: mîna ayahciyiniwah nisto êh-nipahât awa nâpêsis, miywêyihtamwak ôk âyisiyiniwak, êh-miyawâtahkik, êh-nimihitocik, awaw ohci nâpêsis osâm ê-sôhkêyimiht, tâpwê nâpêhkâsôw! êy-itêyimiht, ôhi mîna nâpêwa êh-kaskatahomiht êkâ kâ-wîh-nakatât, osâm namoya cêskwa mitoni êh-oskinîkit.
sentences.text: mîna ayahciyiniwa nisto ê-nipahât awa nâpêsis miywêyihtamwak ôki ayisiyiniwak ê-miyawâtahkik ê-nîmihitocik awa ohci nâpêsis osâm ê-sôhkêyimiht ê-itêyimiht ôhi mîna nâpêwa ê-kaskatahomiht êkâ kâ-wî-nakatât osâm namôya cêskwa mitoni ê-oskinîkit
sentences.english: also because  the boy had slain three Blackfoot those people were glad, and celebrated the outcome with a dance, thinking that boy very brave, thinking of him, “Truly, he is a brave warrior!” especially because he had refused to abandon the wounded man, even though he was not yet full-grown.
That was why those people were glad.
This is where the story ends.
